g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
quity and fairness can serve as both driv
er and barrier to climate mitigation at different scales of
governance. Literature regularly highlights equity and justice issues as critical components in local politics
and international diplomacy regarding all SDG, such as goals for no poverty, zero hun
affordable clean energy, reducing inequality, but also for climate action (Goal 13)
, as it is hard to agree on
level of greenhouse gas mitigation (or emissions) and how
between mitigation costs and damage costs of climate change depe
considered unfair may be hard to implement
experimental economics show that people may not accept a distribution that is considered unfair, even if
there is a cost of not accepting
. As equity issues are important for reaching deep
the transition towards a sustainable development
on taking equity seriously in climate policies and international
(Martinez et al. 2019; Okereke and Coventry 2016; Klinsky et al. 2017)
climate policies affect countries and people differently
be more dependent on primary industries (agriculture, fisheries, etc.) than
may be less robust to tackle more severe weather c
unequal social structures can result in women being more vulnerable to the effects of climate
(Jost et al. 2016; Rao et al. 2019; Arora
. Costs of mitigation also differ across countries. Studies show there are large disparities of economic
impacts of NDCs across regions, and also between relatively similar countries whe
n it comes to the level
of development, due to large differences in marginal abatement cost for the emission reduction
(Akimoto et al. 2018; Fujimori et al. 2016; Edmonds et al. 2019; Hof et al. 2017)
ive more support for mitigation policies
aking equity into account in designing an i
nternational climate agreement is complicated as there is no
, and countries may strategically choose a criterion that favours
. Still, several studies analyse the consequences of different social
preferences in designing climate agreements, such as for inst
. Religion, values, culture, gender, identity, social status and habits strongly influence individual
behaviours and choices and therefore, sustainable consumption
dentities can provide powerful attachments to consumption activities and objects that
